Award.AwardTitle: The Co-evolution of Brightest Cluster Galaxies and Intracluster Light
Award.AbstractNarration:
Clusters of galaxies are important probes of cosmology and are key players in unraveling the mysteries behind galaxy formation and evolution and the development of large scale structure in the Universe. This project aims to investigate the co-evolution of brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs) and intracluster light (ICL) over the past 8 billion years. The study's objectives for understanding galaxy formation are to understand the physical origin of ICL and to quantify the size and stellar mass growth of BCGs. The objectives driven by cosmological considerations are to quantify the fraction of stellar baryons in the BCG plus ICL as a function of cluster mass and redshift and the cluster-to-cluster variation in this stellar baryon fraction and to conduct the definitive census of total (gas plus stellar) baryon fraction as a function of cluster mass.

Previous studies have had data limitations requiring several crude approximations, such as assuming a constant mass-to-light ratio for all cluster galaxies and using background subtraction rather than spectroscopic cluster membership to determine the total cluster galaxy luminosity. Previous work has also lacked the combination of gas and stellar baryon data for individual clusters. The proposed work will serve as a definitive survey that includes deep spectroscopy, X-ray data, and deep photometry for the galaxy population and ICL for a statistical sample of clusters, thereby replacing the earlier crude approximations with actual measurements governed by statistics---broadly important to the scientific community.

Educationally, the proposed activities will promote teaching and training of a graduate student and a postdoctoral associate. The principal investigator will continue to co-lead an outreach program with local high schools, including a workshop for roughly 30 high school students that targets underserved communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this research project was to investigate the population of intracluster stars in galaxy clusters.  In recent years it has been realized that a substantial fraction of all the stars in a galaxy cluster no longer reside in the galaxies where they formed, but rather have been removed from these galaxies and have orbits defined only by the full galaxy cluster gravitational potential. In this work we have investigated three questions: 

(1) How are stars removed from the galaxies in which they form?

(2) How much does the distribution and importance of intracluster stars vary from cluster to cluster?

(3) How does the way in which normal (baryonic) matter is partitioned between stars and hot, intracluster gas depend upon the cluster mass?

One key result from this program is based upon work in which we have conducted a very careful census of the hot gas (using the XMM satellite), the galaxies, and the intracluster stars. We found that the fraction of normal matter in stars is a very strong function of galaxy cluster mass, but for a given cluster mass there is very little variation in the ratio of stars to gas between clusters. Our results also indicate that there is a significant scatter in the ratio of normal to dark matter with cluster cores, particularly for the lowest mass systems.

A second key result from this program is based upon an analysis of intracluster stars for a sample of galaxy clusters observed with the Hubble Space Telescope. We have found that the intracluster stellar population gets progressively bluer with increasing distance from the central cluster galaxy, probing out to approximately 100 kiloparsecs in radius. The color trends we observe can be interpreted as gradients in the elemental abundances (metallicities) of the intracluster stars. These trends are consistent with this stellar population being the result of some combination of tidal stripping of stars from the outskirts of Milky Way size galaxies and tidal destruction of much lower mass galaxies.  Our observations rule out mergers of galaxies onto the central galaxy as a significant source of intracluster stars.  When combined with the quantity of intracluster stars, which is typically more than four times the stellar mass of our own Milky Way galaxy, these observations strongly favor the interpretation that most intracluster stars are the result of tidal stripping of stars from galaxies with masses greater than one-sixth that of the Milky Way.

In conjunction with the above research program, the PI also organized and co-led a series of free astronomy workshops for high school students from across north and north-central Florida. Workshops were each two days in length and designed to provide astronomy education via hands-on activities.
